results.title: Voici le Temps des Assassins = a Time for Murder
results.creator_credit: Julien Duvivier, Charles Borderie and Robert Bossis
results.brief_description:
Andre Chatelain is a quiet, middle-aged restaurant owner in Les Halles district of Paris. His life becomes unexpectedly complicated when Catherine pays a visit. She introduces herself as the daughther of his late ex-wife. Moved by the distress of Catherine, Andre invites her to stay with him. Soon after, Gerard, Andre’s adopted son, is smitten by the young woman. But she makes it clear she is only interested in Andre. Andre, however, suspects the young woman to be a liar and possibly a psychotic, mixed up with a number of underworld types. This film offers a very realistic depiction of the life and activities of Les Halles at the time it was considered as the ‘belly of Paris’. The title song is interpreted by Germaine Montero.

Credits: Producers, Charles Borderie, Robert Bossis ; director, Julien Duvivier ; writers, Julien Duvivier, Maurice Bessy, Charles Dorat ; photography, Armand Thirard ; music, Jean Wiener.
Cast: Jean Gabin, Daniele Delorme, Grerad Blain, Germaine Kerjean, Lucienne Bogaert, Robert Arnoux, Jean-Paul Roussillon, Robert Manuel.

results.title: The Man from Snowy River
results.brief_description: The Man From Snowy River, based on the classic Australian poem by Banjo Patterson, tells the story of an 18 year old boy who proves himself a man during an unforgettable chase on horseback down the rugged Snowy Mountains and becomes a legend. The most magnificent footage of horses ever filmed.

constellations_other.name: The ‘Australian' alps
constellations_other.description: These feature films and documentaries show how stories have been told to lay claim - and reclaim - the land and our national identity.

constellations_other.name: Great southern land?
constellations_other.description: Australia is often mythologised in film and TV, but national myths must not only be embraced, but resisted.

results.title: The Silenced
results.credit_line:
Julie Gough

Single-channel video, sound, 6:18 mins.

ACMI Collection

Edited by Jemma Rae
results.material_description: Single-channel video, HDMI 4k video projection, 16:9, colour, sound, 6:18 min
results.brief_description: In works such as The Silenced, Trawlwoolway artist Julie Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories, interrogating colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

constellations_other.name: Keep the fire burning
constellations_other.description: Yanmeeyarr, meaning ‘flickering in firelight’, shares how light and shadow are at the core of the moving image. It reflects the past, present and future of stories told by First Peoples utilising these elements, as well as bringing to light stories that have, for too long, been kept in the dark.

results.description:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples. In works such as The Silenced Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.” – Julie Gough
description_for_label:
Julie Gough is a Trawlwoolway artist, writer and curator who lives in Hobart, Tasmania. Gough works across many mediums including video, sound and installation. Her work interrogates colonialism and its impact on Tasmania’s First Peoples.

In works such as The Silenced, Gough uncovers and re-presents subsumed and often conflicting histories. These works are often deeply personal, referring to her own and her family’s experiences as Tasmanian Aboriginal people.

“At least 185 Aboriginal children in Lutruwita / Van Diemen’s Land / Tasmania lived with colonists before the 1850s. The Silenced is an introduction to the task of finding these children within slim records. Reinstating them back on the Country they lived, isolated from their dead and exiled kin, amongst the colonists responsible, clearly reveals the genocidal intent of Empire.”

results.title: Scripture for a smoke screen: Episode 1 – dolphin house
results.creator_credit: Amrita Hepi, Luke Smith and Zoe Theodore
results.brief_description:
“I’m interested in exploring the gulf between lived experience and its representation, and how identity and ideas around intelligence are constantly being shaped, amplified or flattened through the experience of surveillance and misidentification.”

In the 1960s, scientists tried to talk to dolphins. The experiment was backed by NASA, who were investigating ways to communicate with extra-terrestrial life. One intelligence test attempted to determine self-awareness by seeing if the dolphins recognised themselves in a mirror.

Amrita Hepi draws on that trial in “Scripture for a smokescreen: Episode 1 – dolphin house”, seemingly seducing her own image. She dances with an inflatable dolphin, attempting to communicate with it through voice and movement, paralleling the intimacy between one of the researchers, Margaret Lovatt, and a male dolphin during the experiment.

Not only does Amrita lampoon the absurdity of teaching marine mammals English, she uses the study to expose the way Western knowledge systems – language, ethics and science – are imposed on people and cultures through colonisation. Through choreographed dance and moving image, Amrita explores what happens when we’re constantly under surveillance, and when assumptions about us are presented to the world through someone else’s viewpoint.

Amrita Hepi is represented by Anna Schwartz Gallery

constellations_other.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_other.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

constellations_other.name: Human rhythm
constellations_other.description: Presence is human form in digital motion. Creating from motion capture of real dancers, it’s the starting point in this Constellation exploring robots and digital choreography.

results.title: A Man and his dog
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board and Supreme Sound Studios
results.brief_description: An account of the training of Kelpie dogs in the handling of sheep on an Australian sheep station. Explains the possible origin of the breed; shows the special training a dog receives from the time he is a small pup until he can muster and control a mob of a thousand or more sheep; shows the confidence of the dog and the bond of friendship which springs up between the animals and their masters.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian National Film Board and Supreme Sound Studios

results.title: World Series Debating: That Football is Stupid
results.creator_credit: Andrew Denton, Ted Robinson, Joe Murray, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Wendy Harmer
results.brief_description: One of the most popular events of the annual Melbourne Comedy Festival, the debate was filmed over several years by ABC TV. Campbell McComas introduces two teams of 3 people consisting of Wendy Harmer, Edmund Capon, Lex Marinos, HG Nelson, Laurie Lawrence, Andrew Denton. The topic of this debate is that football is stupid.

results.title: Blue Murder: Part 2
results.creator_credit: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Based on the events that led to the Royal Commission on Police Corruption in New South Wales, ‘Blue Murder’ is a riveting and exceptionally well executed thriller about police corruption and gangland criminal activity in 1980s Australia.
Richard Roxburgh is outstanding as Roger Rogerson, the larrikin police chief who built a lucrative ‘alternative’ career based on bribery, drug money and murder. Tony Martin is Neddy Smith, one of Australia’s most notorious underworld thugs.
Rogerson and Smith’s activities are threatened when a young police officer, Michael Drury (Steve Bastoni), declines a bribe offered to him by Rogerson. From that moment on, ‘Blue Murder’ depicts how Drury’s involvement in acting as an informer on Rogerson’s activities led to increasingly desperate and murderous acts by both police and crims.
Acclaimed internationally as a landmark television mini-series, ‘Blue Murder’ was for years unable to be screened in NSW or available for view on video in Australia due to elements of the story being seen as prejudicial to legal trials in NSW and Federal Courts.
Cast also inlcudes Alex Dimitriades, Peter Phelps and John Hargreaves.
First broadcast (outside NSW) September 21st, 1995.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michael Jenkins, Rod Allan, Australian Broadcasting Corporation, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Southern Star Entertainment

results.title: Sept Visions Fugitives
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and colour and audio
results.brief_description: Sept Visions Fugitives was produced in China. Cahen creates impressionistic transformations of landscape and people. He writes: “The looking and listening audiences are confronted — in addition to the pure impressions — with basic questions about work (the boy using a traditional device to shake the feathers from the mattress) about freedom, about life in China … and ultimately about life and death: the burial, the bird, the man with a sheaf of straw on his back symbolizing the passage, the beyond ….. I had to struggle to make what I know are stereotyped images my own. The pure impressions and raw filmic material are completely reworked, going much further than the original takes.” Source: Electronic Arts Intermix [www.eai.org]

results.title: Catalyst: Fire Storm
results.creator_credit: Andrew Holland, Ian Cuming and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
A scientific investigation into the causes of the catastrophic Canberra bushfires of January 2003 where 474 homes were destroyed and four lives lost. Includes interviews with residents, scientists, environmentalists and fire-fighters.
Episode from the ABC TV series ‘Catalyst’ presented and narrated by Karina Kelly.
